notesStmt.note: [NOTES: A. O’Henley’s note on the first page – “Made available courtesy of Mrs Alexander Nicolson and Dr Alistair MacLean, Bernisdale, Isle of Skye.”]

entry.def: woollen manufacture. “Chan eil snàthain air a dhruim gus a’ bhoineid tha air a cheann nach b’e abhras.”
applied to an exceptionally small boat.
their like, equal. “Chan fhacas riamh an àicheadh.”
genitive of ‘aimsir’. “Tha mise an deireadh na h-aimsreach.”
a wall dividing township pasture from hill pasture.
stormy petrel. Small petrels whose presence taken as a sign of oncoming storms.
a shelving slope. “’Se Coire Cheathaich an aithir phrìseil.”
tottering especially with drink. “Anns an amaidaich.”
if bad fortune fell on someone repetitively. “’S ann dha a bha an cruadal amasach.”
on the verge, about to do.
in sense of distress. “Bha mi nis air m’fhàgail ’s an an uair.”
downpouring of continous rain. “Di-haoine ghlac an t-aoineadh na bheul e.” Means that if heavy rain begins on Friday morning it will continue all day.
particular example. “Gabhaidh sinn seo mar àraidh.”
treatment. “Fhuair e droch atach.” Proverb: “Atach seann seòladair, atach a mios a th’ann.”
the soul having left the body?, breath.
twilight. Also ‘athadh’. “Beul an atha [sic] ’s an anmoich.”
slow, dim witted. Also: “Air a bhaghaiste fhein.” – on his own free will, daltist [?] way.
a shinty game. See An Gaidheal 1956.
believed to be the name of the coracle that took Columba to Iona.
used of cloth that is coarse and thick in texture. Also used of a person who had grown too fat.
any kind of bandage, e.g. used on a child.
bark of birch tree. Used as tinder. Often saturated with grease or oil.
Goddess of Winter. The enemy of St. Bride. See Cailleach Bheir.
new wool growing under the old fleece before the latter is cut.
a hiding place on moor. Usually a cave whose entrance is covered by heather.
spyhole. “Toll beag a bhigire a bha air an dorus.”
gap between outside and inside wall.
underpart of body of quadrup[ed], fish, flank.
a cow demanded by the chief at Halloween.
cow demanded by lord on death of a vassal.
wetness, water, sea. “An sgadan a’ snàmh ’sa bhoinnearachd.”
a large lump of bread. Also ‘grobhd’ in W. Ross.
used in connection with a violent death. “Rinn iad braidseal dheth.”
a low platform under a table or dresser and projecting from it. Often used as a stance for pails of water.
bereft of. “Chaidh am fàgail braon am beachd.”
describing music that is fast and loud.
yellow wagtail. [Cf. breacadan buidhe nan allt.]
yellow wagtail. [Cf. breacan buidhe nan allt.]
holes in sides of creels used for lifting creel.
large pot in which Feinne cooked their food. Also secret language of tinkers.
a guess wide of the mark.
piece of wool nearest shin. Considered inferior.
in Irish it is a poem not meant to be sung.
a chewed rag. Also chewing, grinding with teeth.
a young salmon before it enters salt water. Parr.
a plait of straw made into a bag.
service given by squatter to landlord.
the impost on a successor to land.
large quantity of something unwanted, undesired.
chief of band of itinerant bards.
extracted on tenant by proprietor of each ursainn, caora chàraidh, etc.
gaming. “Bha iad ri cearrachas.” Also means skill in playing games.
’S ann a cheart eiginn ’s a dh’aindheoin a dh’aithnicheas bean a ceud leanabh. – proverb.
to have a go. “Bheir sinn cearrag air.”
monster that flew with St. Ronan from Eurobay to N. Rona.
to steady your aim. “Chinntich e a ghunna.”
confound you. Also string to bind toes of deceased. Same as ‘spriollag’ in Uist.
sniggering, giggling. Also in sense of rising waves in choppy sea.
be-he-moth. Job 40:15-24. Believed to be a hippopotamus, I think?
a monster taking the shop [sic] [shape?] of a man. “Chan eil ann ach ciuthach de dhuine.”
warning stone, slab. Same as clach fharachaidh.
three large waves that occur at intervals at sea.
a victim, totally vanquished. “Rinn iad coileach dubh dheth.”

crozier of St. Fillan, custodians of which were Dewars of Glendochart also called “Fearachd”, see “Deoraich na Fearachd”. The relic was present at Bannockburn. Found in Canada where taken by custody 1870. Now in Edinburgh.
peg to which hounds were tied.
metrical device whereby the last word of one line is repeated in the next.
a request made by a dying person and therefore binding.
fretful. Especially used of a child. (Skye)
willy nilly. “Theid thu ann gad chosg.” (Skye)
stinking urchin. Also a disagreeable person.
small pancake, made of flour, switched eggs and milk.
a wheeze or crickle in your voice.
a sort of dance. See Caraid nan Gaidheal p. 398.
composition in which prose satire is interspersed with poetry.
rate of imposing fines for injuries (clans, septs, etc.).
final process in tweed making before fulling.
a cut at root of toe.
in the sense of an archer.
one who does not force payments of debts.
a type of dance. See Caraid nan Gaidheal p. 398.
originally keeper of relics of a saint.
beach or rough shingle. Isthmus of dry land.
belittling. “Bha e dolach air na fhuair e.”
Troigh is dòrn gulban – a game played by children in Uist. See T.G.S.I. vol. 2 p. 35.
lowest horizontal rope on a thatched house. ‘Anchors’ tied to this. This would be the equivalent of ‘màthair shìamain’ in other islands.
also insense [sic] [in sense? incense?] of alder tree.
carcase of sheep found on hill.
double low A strike in pìobaireachd.
sorry for. “B’fhada leam de thachair dha.”
impression, to remember. “Tha failbhe agam air.”
eagle or hawk in some editions of the Bible.
difficult task, job. “B’e sin am fàiseach.”
debility. Also Zephyr, i.e. soft gentle wind or breeze from west.
trying to force your way in or out.
attending to topsails of a boat.
sea plantain [?], choice pasture for cattle and sheep.
reason. “Dè thug fochann dhut bhi ann.”
smoothing down rough tillage. Also hobby, pastime.
a shot from a gun, etc.
dried sedge. Carried as a lighted torch at Halloween.
region of face, close to mouth. Cheek? From Latin ‘gena’?
whiteness of tongue, trouble in infancy.
flatterers. Iain Lom ‘Lament for Sir L. MacLean’.
stoppage of music to listen to better music.
type of sandstone. Similar to goinneal?
spats. Short gaiter for instep and ankle.
heat of sun after emerging from clouds.
open, loose fitting. Clothes of inferior quality.
tacking a garment. Also pursing the lips.
goddess of fertility of flocks. Offerings of milk made to her on Mondays before sunrise. Placed in a hollow on top of Gruagach stone.
also tack taken by a boat.
haunched person or bird sitting in a ball shape.
stoppage, halt. “Cha deach iadnach air fad an latha.”
solicitation? “Fo eagal ’s fo ímdith.” Neil Morrison’s ‘Oran Gaoil’. Leabhar nan Gleann p. 49.
skin used as a lid to cover kegs and other vessels. Prior to days of lids.
dirt on haunches of housed cattle.
shirt placed on one in church who had committed a sexual misdemeanour such as adultery.
healing by passing a child through hoop of fire.
flat pebbles, skimming across surface of water.
afterbirth of animals. That of humans always burnt to prevent fairies from stealing babies.
a sink, liquid in motion, hard drinker.
a potent panacea. After one of the Beatons. T.G.S.I. Vol. 37 p. 203.
a harp string of exceptional music power.
alone, at own will, retired, on holiday.
pauper boy maintained by Sunday collection in Church. (Skye)
a sort of charm. See Caraid nan Gaidheal p. 338.
champion’s portion. Also as greim curaidh.
villeinage. Unfree peasant attached to lord to whom he paid dues and services for his land.
stance for shared boat. Also nòs.
said of cattle lacking inclination for food.
mortar used for pounding grain into meal.
[?] trail of moving object in water.
cited and composed poems in travelling band.
[sic] tearing a person limb from body tied between two horses. “Air a’ riathadh, riaghadh.”
sickness in cattle due to overfeeding.
a sacred piece of soil reserved for burials.
narrow neck of land from promontory to mainland and from one mountain to another.
conscious view as opposed to ‘seall aislinge’.
person who acts wiser than he actually is. Also a steward.
spitting as in a wild cat or fox. (Skye)
large wooden spade shod with iron. Used by man who laid and smoothed furrows in days of first ploughs.
a prophetic voice heard on rare occasions by certain individuals. A sort of ‘second hearing’.
to give up, e.g. on a cause.
dejected look. Sgiuigean (-ire) – one so affected.
emaciated person, bag of bones. Especially used of a female.
premonetary [sic] [premonitory?] sensation on lips, e.g. “Tha sgrìoban do phòg orm.”
depressing, sun going down in west.
having a good go at something, belly full.
falling flat on your front. “Thuit mi air mo splaidheagan.”
sink head foremost, anything that sinks rapidly.
making faces in pain or in sorrow.
draw flesh, fowl or fish off bones by lips and teeth.
streaming. Also to press forward with difficulty.
take off, trigger, stance in leaping, etc.
mush of boiled potatoes and shellfish.
butter. (Ardnamurchan) [NOTES: ‘stop-churn’ is underlined indicating that it is the catch-word. Was only ‘stop’ meant to be underlined?]
to drive sheep from an area.
waterhole in which animals can get bogged down.
green field in waste or heathery land.
opportunity in sense of a break in time, e.g. lunchtime.
iron pot used in parching oats.
hill with good prospect. Occurs in placenames.
fixture. Iain Lom ‘Oran an aghaidh an Aonaidh’.
fire lit when seeking help. Summons to doctor to island without a physician.
bag made of roots of bedstraw or matgrass in which corn was parched over a fire.
cut by one sweep of scythe or shears on wool.
one who carried his master’s baggage.
bread and cheese given with a dram.
loch that dries up in summer.
filling between inner and outer walls.
thick cream with oatmeal. Also as ‘ollag’ in Sutherland.
to notice a change in someone.
Gertrude. Temporary name applied immediately after birth. Lay baptism by nurse consisting of three drops of water.
Tower of London. Vide ‘Lament for Angus of Glengarry’. Gaelic Bards p. 179.
